title: 103_s1603
content: The Civil Service Retirement System is discussed in Section 1. The Civil Service Retirement System is discussed in Section 1. Definitions and amendments related to fish and wildlife officers in the United States Code are outlined, including changes to deductions, contributions, and deposits. In Section 8336 of the Civil Service Retirement System, amendments are made to include fish and wildlife officers for service alongside law enforcement officers and firefighters. SEC. 2. FEDERAL EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM. The amendment to title 5 of the United States Code includes defining a 'fish and wildlife officer' as a law enforcement officer of the Refuge Division of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. It also allows for immediate retirement benefits for fish and wildlife officers under the Federal Employees Retirement System. The amendment to title 5 of the United States Code includes adding "fish and wildlife officer" to various sections related to retirement benefits, alongside firefighters and air traffic controllers. This change allows for immediate retirement benefits for fish and wildlife officers under the Federal Employees Retirement System. Amendment to title 5 of the United States Code adds "fish and wildlife officer" to retirement benefits sections, allowing for immediate retirement benefits under the Federal Employees Retirement System. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. Employee contributions are required for individuals who served as fish and wildlife officers before the Act's effective date to receive credited service and annuities. The Department of the Interior must also make contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund within 90 days of the individual's payment. The Office of Personnel Management determines Disability Fund contributions for individuals as if the Act's amendments were in effect during their service. OPM also decides interest amounts and may create regulations for implementation. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 90 days after enactment.
